subject: Re: Shaw Alphabet Books is now online.
msgSnippet: ... And to you. ... Interesting. Were you able to make out the fonts at all? For the record, there s not really any info about the books yet. It s basically
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Sid Tanaban <sidban2@...> wrote:

> A happy new year to you, Tim!

And to you.

> I went to your book on Poe and Shaw but it was too black to read
> anything about your new book.

Interesting. Were you able to make out the fonts at all? For the record, there's not really any info about the books yet. It's basically set up like a movie poster for now, just saying that it's "Coming Soon [TM]" and not much else. There's not so much as a single clickable link yet. I will be adding more information to the page at a later date.

> Congratulations on finishing it.

Thanks! :-)

> I studied Shaws Alphabet, switched to Quikskript but thought
> again about whether Shaws Alphabet was faster to learn to read or
> not than Quikskript. I would be curious to know why you rejected
> Quikskript for Shaws. Or, could you send me a website where I
> could see why others retained Shaw over Read's alphabet?

Well, I just prefer the look and feel of the original over the new one. When I saw the Shaw Alphabet for the first time back on April 16th, 2002, I thought it was one of the most beautiful writing systems I'd ever seen, so much so that 2 days later I became determined to do something about it when I found out that it was the only book published in the alphabet. Quikskript... not so much. I read through the QuikSkript guide and ended up with more questions than answers. I found it really confusing and there appeared to be many instances where things that look identical could be pronounced differently. For example, Read said that you could use the ng character to represent the suffix -ing. For example, would Commander Data's creator be Noonien Soong, or Noonien Suing? In the Shaw Alphabet it's obvious, but in the Read Alphabet you can never be sure. I have the same basic issue with Paul Vandenbrink's "Shaw Alphabet" in how he merged ALL of the vowels into 2-3 characters, so good luck trying to read a story about the 5 sisters Jane, Jan, Jen, Joan, June and their brother John. Wow, I hope that I didn't just completely alienate this group as potential customers with this message...
